parts:
Here’s a tightly-curated, algebraic-topology–friendly bibliography on CGWH (= compactly generated, weak Hausdorff) spaces, with quick notes on what each source does best and where to look for construction, motivation, categorical properties, and use in homotopy theory.

# Core, single-stop expositions (start here)

1) **Neil Strickland — “The Category of CGWH Spaces” (2009, 23pp).**  
A self-contained, modern, point-set–meets-category-theory treatment. Defines k-ification and weak Hausdorff, proves stability under limits/colimits, explains mapping-space topologies and exponential laws, and gives the hard-to-find statements about how limits and colimits interact in CGWH. Ideal first read if you already know general topology. citeturn3view0

2) **NLab pages (living references).**  
- *Convenient category of topological spaces*: overview of why one wants a “convenient” subcategory (cartesian closedness, good colimits) with links to variants. citeturn2search0  
- *Compactly generated topological space*: categorical properties (cartesian closedness of kTop, motivations), relationships among definitions. citeturn0search7  
- *Classical model structure on topological spaces*: notes how CGWH (and other convenient subcategories) underlie standard model structures. citeturn2search9

3) **Wikipedia summaries (fast orientation, check details in Strickland).**  
- *Compactly generated space*: motivations, equivalent definitions (via coherent topology / final topology), and why algebraic topologists care. citeturn0search2  
- *Category of CGWH spaces*: compact statement of completeness, cocompleteness, inclusion of CW and locally compact Hausdorff spaces, etc. citeturn2search15

# Historical and conceptual motivation (“why CGWH?”)

4) **Norman Steenrod — “A convenient category of topological spaces” (Michigan Math. J. 1967).**  
The classic motivation for leaving raw **Top**: failure of cartesian closedness, bad behavior of products and quotients, and the desire for a function-space/exponential law that actually works. Foundational for the “convenience” agenda that CGWH (and siblings) realize. citeturn2search1

5) **Borceux, *Handbook of Categorical Algebra II* (Cambridge).**  
Chapter-level treatment of exponentiable spaces, topological functors, and how restricting to compactly generated spaces recovers cartesian closedness. Use this for the category-theoretic framing of “convenience” (reflective/coreflective subcategories, exponentials, etc.). citeturn5search1

6) **Adámek–Herrlich–Strecker, *Abstract and Concrete Categories: The Joy of Cats*.**  
A broad reference on concrete/topological categories (initial/final structures, topological functors) giving the language to discuss **Top**, kTop, and CGWH categorically; pair it with Strickland for a full categorical perspective. citeturn5search0

# Algebraic-topology practice (how CGWH gets used)

7) **J. P. May — *A Concise Course in Algebraic Topology*, “Compactly generated spaces” sections.**  
May builds homotopical constructions assuming compact generation/weak Hausdorffness; you’ll see how geometric realization, classifying spaces, and colimits are handled cleanly in that setting. (E.g., remarks around compactly generated colimits and product preservation.) citeturn1view0

8) **Jardine (lecture notes): CGWH and the model structure.**  
Concise notes giving characterizations like “X is WH iff the diagonal is closed in X×X,” and where CGWH fits the Serre/Hurewicz model structures. Useful for quick lemmas you’ll actually cite. citeturn0search9

9) **Hovey — *Model Categories* (1999).**  
Standard reference that treats topological model categories; in practice, when you want Quillen structures and enrichment over **Top**, you assume CGWH (or a close cousin) so that mapping spaces and monoidal structures behave. citeturn0search8turn0search13

10) **Mandell–May–Schwede–Shipley — “Model Categories of Diagram Spectra” (2001).**  
Appendices and preliminaries lean on a CGWH-style foundation to control mapping objects, pushouts, and realizations. Read this when you want to see “convenience” powering serious modern homotopy theory. citeturn4search0

# What to read for specific themes

- **Construction (k-ification and WH reflection).**  
Strickland §1 defines k-closed sets via tests against maps from compact Hausdorff spaces; kX is the finest k-topology below the given one, and WH means images of compact Hausdorff are closed. Lemma 1.4(c) is the handy internal test “Y is k-closed iff Y∩K is closed for every compact-Hausdorff subspace K⊆X.” citeturn3view0

- **Why algebraic topologists use CGWH.**  
Top is not cartesian closed; the compact-open topology on C(X,Y) fails to be exponential in general, products misbehave with identifications, and pushouts can be pathological. CGWH fixes these pathologies “just enough”: you get exponential laws with the k-ified compact-open topology, better behavior of pushouts (e.g., along closed inclusions), and colimits that play well with homotopy theory (geometric realization, cell attachments). For a compact motivation list, see Wikipedia and Strickland; for a community perspective, also see MathOverflow discussions. citeturn0search2turn2search6

- **Categorical properties (what’s actually true).**  
CGWH is **complete and cocomplete**; limits/colimits are created by the underlying-set functor with mild repairs (k-ify, enforce WH), and the category is **cartesian closed** with function spaces built from the compact-open topology then k-ified. Strickland gives precise pushout/pullback and quotient-stability statements; Wikipedia gives the quick checklist. citeturn3view0turn2search15

- **Model-category context.**  
When you put a Quillen model structure on spaces, the convenient categories (like CGWH) are the right base for enrichment, tensor/cotensor, and simplicial/topological framings. Hovey is the general reference; MMSS shows the pay-off in stable homotopy. citeturn0search8turn4search0

# A minimal “cheat sheet” (facts you’ll reuse)

- **Definitions** (Strickland):  
X is *k* if open/closed sets are detected on compact Hausdorff probes; *WH* if images of compact Hausdorff are closed; **CGWH** = both. Lemma 1.4(c) is your internal test for k-closed subsets. citeturn3view0

- **Exponentials**: CGWH is cartesian closed; mapping spaces are compact-open, then k-ified (so [X→Y] exists, and the exponential law holds). Background “why Top is not cartesian closed” in Borceux/Escardó; “how to fix it” in Strickland. citeturn5search1turn3view0

- **(Co)limits**: Completeness, cocompleteness; pushouts along closed inclusions stay in CGWH; quotients are well-behaved (see Strickland’s Prop. 2.35–2.40-style results). citeturn3view0

- **Homotopy-colimit constructions**: geometric realizations and sequential colimits work as expected (this is where many texts assume CGWH without fanfare). May and MMSS use this constantly. citeturn1view0turn4search0

# How I’d study this efficiently (given your background)

1) Read **Strickland** cover-to-cover once; keep it by your side. citeturn3view0  
2) Skim **Steenrod (1967)** to internalize the classical failure modes in **Top** (and hence the motivation). citeturn2search1  
3) For categorical framing (reflective/coreflective subcategories, exponentials, topological functors), consult **Borceux** and **Joy of Cats** as needed. citeturn5search1turn5search0  
4) When you move into model categories or spectra, check **Hovey** and **MMSS** to see CGWH used in anger. citeturn0search8turn4search0  
5) Keep **NLab** pages open for cross-checking definitions and equivalences. citeturn2search0turn0search7

If you want, I can extract from these sources a compact “CGWH toolkit” (definitions + 10 lemmas + 10 propositions) with proofs aligned to categorical language (adjunctions, exponentials, creation of limits/colimits by the forgetful functor, etc.).
